useStmt.citReq:
Publications and research reports based on the Higher Ed database must cite it appropriately. The citation should include the following:
Minnesota Population Center. IPUMS Higher Ed: Version 1.0 [dataset]. Minneapolis, MN: University of Minnesota, 2016. https://doi.org/10.18128/D100.V1.0
The licensing agreement for use of Higher Ed data requires that users supply us with the title and full citation for any publications, research reports, or educational materials making use of the data or documentation. Please add your citation to the IPUMS bibliography: http://bibliography.ipums.org/
useStmt.conditions:
Users of Higher Ed data must agree to abide by the conditions of use. A user's license is valid for one year and may be renewed. Users must agree to the following conditions:
(1) No fees may be charged for use or distribution of the data. All persons are granted a limited license to use these data, but you may not charge a fee for the data if you distribute it to others.
(2) Cite IPUMS appropriately. For information on proper citation, refer to the citation requirement section of this DDI document.
(3) Tell us about any work you do using the IPUMS. Publications, research reports, or presentations making use of Higher Ed should be added to our Bibliography. Continued funding for the IPUMS depends on our ability to show our sponsor agencies that researchers are using the data for productive purposes.
(4) Use it for GOOD -- never for EVIL.
useStmt.disclaimer: The user of the data acknowledges that the original collector of the data, the authorized distributor of the data, and the relevant funding agency bear no responsibility for use of the data or for interpretations or inferences based upon such uses.

fileTxt.filePlac: IPUMS, 50 Willey Hall, 225 - 19th Avenue South, Minneapolis, MN 55455

var.name: PERSONID
var.labl: Individual identification number
var.txt:
PERSONID is an identification variable constructed by IPUMS using the reference ID variable (REFID) from the public use files. The original variable identifying individuals uniquely across samples is composed of alpha-numerics, whereas PERSONID used an algorithm to create unique numeric values for each individual. Each digit was expanded to 2 digits. Numeric digits were given a leading zero. For example, the digit 2 would be converted to 02. Letters would be converted by the ordinal of the letter plus ten. For example, A would be converted to 11, B to 12, C to 13 and so on. It is possible to identify individuals in different survey years within the same decade.
IPUMS-SESTAT has set PERSONID as a character string for statistical packages to more easily read in the values.
Users should note that some respondents are interviewed over time, allowing the possibility for longitudinal data analysis. Please see our User Note on Longitudinal Data.
var.codInstr: This is a 18-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: YEAR
var.labl: Survey year
var.txt: YEAR gives the year in which the survey was administered.
var.codInstr: This is a 4-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: WEIGHT
var.labl: SESTAT weight
var.txt:
WEIGHT is a weight variable specific to SESTAT samples. The original weights for the separate, non-SESTAT surveys were adjusted to create WEIGHT, so that individuals who might have been eligible for more than one survey are not over-represented when analyzing the entire SESTAT file for a particular year.
Users should use WTSURVY for non-SESTAT survey samples.
The original data includes the decimal point and 2 decimal places.
var.codInstr: WEIGHT is an 11-digit numeric variable with a decimal point and 2 decimal places.

var.name: SAMPLE
var.labl: Sample identifier
var.txt:
SAMPLE is an IPUMS-design sample identification number to distinguish each SESTAT sample uniquely.
The sample coding convention is as follows: the left-most digit (or two digits in 4-digit codes) sequentially numbers each iteration of survey waves beginning in 1993, the second from the right digit identifies SESTAT samples with "0", and non-SESTAT (full survey) samples with "1", and the right-most digit corresponds to the survey type, for example, SDR samples have a last digit of 2.

var.name: SURID
var.labl: Survey identifier
var.txt: SURID identifies the survey for which the respondent was interviewed in this particular survey year.

var.name: RESPLCUS
var.labl: Respondent location
var.txt: RESPLCUS indicates whether or not the respondent was located in the US or not, using information from other responses, such as respondent's residence or employer's location.

var.name: DGRDG
var.labl: Type of highest certificate or degree
var.txt: DGRDG reports the type of the respondent's highest postsecondary degree or certificate.

var.name: HDAY5
var.labl: Year of highest degree pre-2003 (5 year intervals)
var.txt: HDAY5 reports the year, recoded to intervals, in which the respondent received his/her highest degree. The variable HD03Y5 provides similar information for different samples.

var.name: NDGMED
var.labl: Field of major for highest degree
var.txt: NDGMED provides the respondent's field of major for his/her highest degree. The variable NDGMEMG provides this information with a broader level of detail.

catgry.labl: Other biological, agricultural, environmental life sciences

var.name: HDRGN
var.labl: Location of school awarding highest degree
var.txt: HDRGN reports the location of the school from which the respondent received his or her highest degree.

var.name: HDDGRUS
var.labl: School awarding highest degree located in the US
var.txt: HDDGRUS identifies whether or not the academic institution where the respondent received his/her highest degree was located in the United States or not. Due to the sample design of the SDR survey, SDR respondents have all received their doctorate (which is their highest degree) from an institution in the US. See our Survey Designs User Note for more information.

var.name: HDFERN
var.labl: Financial support for highest degree: earnings from employment
var.txt: HDFERN indicates whether or not the respondent depended on earnings from employment as financial support during his/her highest post-secondary degree. The respondent was asked to indicate all sources of financial support that applied. Other variables from this survey question include HDFAST, HDFEM, HDFGFT, HDFGRN, HDFLN, HDFOT, and HDFPLN.

var.name: MRDG
var.labl: Type of degree, most recent degree
var.txt: MRDG indicates the type of degree the respondent received most recently.

var.name: MR03Y5
var.labl: Year of most recent degree (5-year intervals, 2003+)
var.txt: MR03Y5 reports the year, in 5-year intervals, in which the respondent received his/her most recent degree, post 2003. MR5YR reports similar information, but prior to 2003.

var.name: MRDGRUS
var.labl: School awarding most recent degree located in the US
var.txt: MRDGRUS reports whether or not the academic institution from which the respondent received his/her most recent post-secondary degree was located in the United States.

var.name: HSYRGR
var.labl: Year received high school diploma (group)
var.txt: HSYRGR reports the year the respondent received his/her high school diploma, in 5-year intervals.

var.name: LFSTAT
var.labl: Labor force status
var.txt: LFSTAT is the respondent's labor force status.

var.name: FPTIND
var.labl: Full-time/part-time status
var.txt: FPTIND indicates whether or not a respondent was working full time or part-time, if he/she was working during the reference week.

var.name: EXPFT
var.labl: Full-time, years of professional work experience
var.txt: EXPFT gives the respondent's years of full-time, professional work experience.
var.codInstr: This is a 2-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: EXPPT
var.labl: Part-time, years of professional work experience
var.txt: EXPPT gives the respondent's years of part-time, professional work experience.
var.codInstr: This is a 2-digit numeric variable with 0 implied decimal places

var.name: LOSEJOB
var.labl: Concerned about losing job
var.txt: LOSEJOB indicates whether or not the respondent was concerned about losing his/her job in the next 12 months.

var.name: PTWTFT
var.labl: Working part-time but wanted to work full-time
var.txt: PTWTFT indicated whether or not respondents who worked part time actually wanted to be working full time.

var.name: PTFAM
var.labl: Reasons for working part-time: family
var.txt: PTFAM indicates that the respondent worked part-time during the reference week because of family reasons. The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTILL, PTNOND, PTOCNA, PTOTP, PTRET, and PTSTU.

var.name: PTNOND
var.labl: Reasons for working part-time: not need/want work
var.txt: PTNOND indicates that the respondent worked part time in the reference week because the respondent did not need to or want to work full time. The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTFAM, PTILL, PTOCNA, PTOTP, PTRET, and PTSTU.

var.name: PTOTP
var.labl: Reasons for working part-time: other
var.txt: PTOTP indicates whether there was a reason other than the reasons listed in the questionnaire to explain why the respondent was working part time during the reference week. The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTFAM, PTILL, PTNOND, PTOCNA, PTRET, and PTSTU.

var.name: PTSTU
var.labl: Reasons for working part-time: student
var.txt: PTSTU indicates whether or not the respondent was working part time because he/she was a student during the reference period. The following variables indicate other reasons for working part time: PTFAM, PTILL, PTNOND, PTOCNA, PTOTP, and PTRET.

var.name: JOBSATIS
var.labl: Job satisfaction
var.txt: JOBSATIS reports how satisfied the respondent is with his/her current job.

var.name: SATADV
var.labl: Satisfaction principal job's opportunities for advancement
var.txt: SATADV indicates whether or not the respondent is satisfied with his/her principal job's advancement opportunities. SATADV is part of a series of questions that measures the respondent's satisfaction with certain aspects of his/her principal job. The other variables include SATBEN, SATCHAL, SATIND, SATLOC, SATRESP, SATSAL, SATSEC, and SATSOC.

var.name: SATCHAL
var.labl: Satisfaction principal job's intellectual challenge
var.txt: SATCHAL indicates whether or not the respondent is satisfied with his/her principal job's intellectual challenge. SATCHAL is part of a series of questions that measures the respondent's satisfaction with certain aspects of his/her principal job. The other variables include SATADV, SATBEN, SATIND, SATLOC, SATRESP, SATSAL, SATSEC, and SATSOC.

var.name: SATRESP
var.labl: Satisfaction principal job's level of responsibility
var.txt: SATRESP indicates whether or not the respondent is satisfied with his/her principal job's level of responsibility. SATRESP is part of a series of questions that measures the respondent's satisfaction with certain aspects of his/her principal job. The other variables include SATADV, SATBEN, SATCHAL, SATIND, SATLOC, SATSAL, SATSEC, and SATSOC.

var.name: SATSAL
var.labl: Satisfaction principal job salary
var.txt: SATSAL indicates whether or not the respondent is satisfied with his/her principal job's salary. SATSAL is part of a series of questions that measures the respondent's satisfaction with certain aspects of his/her principal job. The other variables include SATADV, SATBEN, SATCHAL, SATIND, SATLOC, SATRESP, SATSEC, and SATSOC.

var.name: SATSOC
var.labl: Satisfaction principal job's contribution to society
var.txt: SATSOC indicates whether or not the respondent is satisfied with the contribution to society of his/her principal job. SATSOC is part of a series of questions that measures the respondent's satisfaction with certain aspects of his/her principal job. The other variables include SATADV, SATBEN, SATCHAL, SATIND, SATLOC, SATRESP, SATSAL, and SATSEC.

var.name: WKTRNI
var.labl: Attended work-related training
var.txt: WKTRNI indicates whether or not the respondent had attended a work-related training, workshop, or seminar within the last twelve months, not including college coursework towards a degree program.

var.name: SPNAT
var.labl: Technical expertise required by spouse/partner job: sciences
var.txt: SPNAT indicates whether or not the job of the respondent's spouse required the spouse to have technical expertise in engineering, computer science, math, or natural sciences at the bachelor degree level or higher. Related variables include SPOT and SPSOC.

var.name: SPOT
var.labl: Technical expertise required by spouse/partner job: other
var.txt: SPOT indicates whether or not the job of the respondent's spouse required the spouse to have technical expertise in a field other than natural or social sciences at the bachelor degree level or higher. Related variables include SPNAT and SPSOC.

var.name: SPSOC
var.labl: Technical expertise required by spouse/partner Job: social sciences
var.txt: SPSOC indicates whether or not the job of the respondent's spouse required the spouse to have technical expertise in social sciences at the bachelor degree level or higher. Related variables include SPNAT and SPOT.
